title: 114_hr1777
content: The "Presidential Allowance Modernization Act of 2016" amends the Former Presidents Act of 1958 to provide each former President with an annuity and allowance of $200,000 per year for life. The annuity and allowance for former Presidents begin the day after they leave office, end upon their death, and are paid monthly by the Treasury Secretary. If a former President holds a paid government position, the annuity and allowance are suspended. Cost-of-living increases are applied annually based on Social Security benefit adjustments. The monetary allowance for former Presidents under the Social Security Act is subject to limitations to ensure it does not exceed a certain amount for a 12-month period. The term 'applicable reduction amount' refers to the reduction in the monetary allowance for former Presidents in a 12-month period. The former President's adjusted gross income and any excluded interest for the most recent taxable year must be considered if it exceeds a certain threshold. The dollar amount specified for cost-of-living increases in the former President's monetary allowance is adjusted based on the same percentage increase. Disclosure requirements include definitions for 'return' and 'return information'. The Secretary of the Treasury or delegate must be disclosed return information by a former President to receive a monetary allowance. Disclosure is confidential under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Secretary must receive return information from a former President to determine a monetary allowance, which must be kept confidential under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Administrator of General Services, in coordination with the Director of the United States Secret Service, will calculate the allowance needed to cover increased business costs due to security needs for a former President. Additionally, surviving spouses of former Presidents are also covered under this provision. The Former Presidents Act of 1958 is amended to increase the monetary allowance for surviving spouses of former Presidents to $100,000 per year. The Former Presidents Act of 1958 is amended to increase the monetary allowance for surviving spouses of former Presidents to $100,000 per year. The amendment removes the reference to the government of the District of Columbia. The Former Presidents Act of 1958 is further amended to include provisions for the widowers of former Presidents, changing references from "widow" to "widow or widower" and from "she" to "she or he". Subsection headings are also added for clarity in the Act. SEC. 3. RULE OF CONSTRUCTION. This Act or any amendments shall not affect laws related to security for former Presidents or their families. SEC. 4. TRANSITION RULES. For former Presidents, the Act's amendments will apply as if the commencement date coincided with the Former Presidents Act of 1958. The Former Presidents Act of 1958, amended by section 2(a), applies to widows of former Presidents. The Act also limits monetary allowances for former Presidents, ensuring they can still meet financial obligations. The Former Presidents Act of 1958, amended to include widows of former Presidents, limits monetary allowances to ensure financial obligations can be met, including lease or contract costs.
